records.text: Bizarrely, there are very few other ways to get hired online. You could zero in on companies you know are hiring or that you already know about, but that limits your pool of options to your own experience. It's actually good for employers and job seekers to have centralized boards where applications are concentrated. But the platforms have a vested interest in their own profits and engagement, which actually sits at odds with job seekers and employers who would rather settle things quickly.

records.text: So each successful match hurts their bottom line. Every time they get one person hired, they lose clients and activity on the site, which decreases the amount they can charge for ad space. Ergo, the logical thing to do is to not prevent someone from getting hired (as that would hurt their reputation) but to only get them hired after an extended search period. The longer it takes for a person to be hired, the more engagement they provide on the way to that goal.
